Docs.summary: Provides paging functionality for data-bound controls that implement the interface, such as the control.

remarks.format: ## Remarks In this topic: - [Introduction](#introduction) - [Pager Fields](#pager_fields) - [Page Properties](#page_properties) - [Accessibility](#Accessibility) - [Declarative Syntax](#DeclarativeSyntax) ## Introduction The class is used to page data and to display navigation controls for data-bound controls that implement the interface. (An example of a control that implements the interface is the control.) You can associate the control with the data-bound control by using the property. Alternatively, you can put the control inside the data-bound control hierarchy. For example, in the control, you can put the control inside the template. You can customize the number of items that are displayed for each page of data by changing the property. You can also change the way a page is submitted to the server by setting the property. ## Pager Fields In order for the control to display navigation controls, you must add pager fields to the control. The pager fields derive from the class. The following table lists the pager field types that you can use. |Pager field type|Description| |----------------------|-----------------| ||Enables users to navigate through pages one page at a time, or to jump to the first or last page.| ||Enables users to select a page by page number.| ||Enables you to create a custom paging UI.| To declaratively add pager fields to the control, add a `Fields` element to the control. You can then add the pager fields to the `Fields` element. The pager fields are added to the collection in the order that they appear in the `Fields` element. The collection enables you to programmatically manage the pager fields in the control. ## Page Properties The following table lists read-only properties of the control that specify characteristics of the page of data. These properties are usually used for binding expressions in the object. |Property|Description| |--------------|-----------------| ||The maximum number of records that are displayed for each page of data.| ||The index of the first record that is displayed on a page of data.| ||The total number of records that are available in the underlying data source.| ## Accessibility The default markup that is rendered default for this control might not comply with accessibility standards, such as the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines 1.0 (WCAG) priority 1 guidelines. For details about accessibility support for this control, see [ASP.NET Controls and Accessibility](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/847a37e3-ce20-41da-b0d3-7dfb0fdae9a0). ## Declarative Syntax ```                                                          ``` ## Examples The following example shows how to add paging functionality to a control. This example contains two controls that are used to page through data of the same control. [!code-aspx-csharp[System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager/CS/DataPagerCS.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager/VB/DataPagerVB.aspx#1)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks To dynamically add a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control to a page, create a new <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> object. Set its properties, and then add it to the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.Controls%2A> collection of a container control, such as a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PlaceHolder> control.
## Examples The following example shows how to use the constructor to dynamically add a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control to a page.

Docs.param: The data-bound control that raises the event.
Docs.summary: Connects events to event handler methods in the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.ConnectToEvents%2A> method specifies the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.OnTotalRowCountAvailable%2A> method as the handler for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.IPageableItemContainer.TotalRowCountAvailable?displayProperty=nameWithType> event of the control specified in `container`. The `container` parameter must contain a data-bound control that implements the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.IPageableItemContainer> interface, such as a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control.
> [!NOTE] > This method is primarily used by control developers to extend the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control.

Docs.summary: Creates the objects that are contained by the property of the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.CreatePagerFields%2A> method is used by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PageSize%2A> property and by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.OnTotalRowCountAvailable%2A> method to create the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerField> objects that are contained by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.Fields%2A> property. This method calls the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerField.CreateDataPagers%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method to create the user interface (UI) controls for each field in the collection.
The pager fields are created in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control in the order that the pager fields appear in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.Fields%2A> collection. The following table shows the pager field classes that derive from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerField> class and that can be created in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control.
|Pager field type|Description| |----------------------|-----------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.NextPreviousPagerField>|Enables users to navigate through pages of data one page at a time, or to jump to the first or last page of data.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.NumericPagerField>|Enables users to select a page of data by page number.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TemplatePagerField>|Enables you to create a custom paging UI.|

Docs.summary: Gets a collection of objects that represent the pager fields that are specified in a control.
Docs.value: A collection object that contains all the pager fields that are specified in the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The pager fields are displayed in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control in the order that the pager fields appear in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.Fields%2A> collection. The following table shows the pager field classes that derive from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerField> class and that can be used in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.Fields%2A> collection.
|Pager field type|Description| |----------------------|-----------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.NextPreviousPagerField>|Enables users to navigate through pages of data one page at a time, or to jump to the first or last page of data.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.NumericPagerField>|Enables users to select a page of data by page number.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TemplatePagerField>|Enables you to create a custom paging UI.|
To declaratively specify the pager fields for a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control, put a `Fields` element inside the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control. You can then list the pager fields you want to include between the opening and closing `<Fields>` tags.
You can programmatically add pager fields to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.Fields%2A> collection. However, it is easier to list the pager fields declaratively in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control.
## Examples The following example shows how to declaratively add pager fields to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.Fields%2A> collection of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control.
[!code-aspx-csharp[System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerField#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerField/CS/DataPagerFieldCS.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerField#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerField/VB/DataPagerFieldVB.aspx#1)]
The following example shows how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.Fields%2A> property to dynamically add a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.NextPreviousPagerField> object to a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.NextPreviousPagerField.%23ctor%2A> constructor.
[!code-csharp[System.Web.UI.WebControls.NextPreviousPagerField.Ctor#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.WebControls.NextPreviousPagerField.Ctor/CS/NextPreviousPagerFieldCtorCS.aspx#2)] [!code-vb[System.Web.UI.WebControls.NextPreviousPagerField.Ctor#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.WebControls.NextPreviousPagerField.Ctor/VB/NextPreviousPagerFieldCtorVB.aspx#2)]

MemberSignature.Value: protected virtual System.Web.UI.WebControls.IPageableItemContainer FindPageableItemContainer ();
.method familyhidebysig newslot virtual instance class System.Web.UI.WebControls.IPageableItemContainer FindPageableItemContainer() cil managed
Protected Overridable Function FindPageableItemContainer () As IPageableItemContainer
protected: virtual System::Web::UI::WebControls::IPageableItemContainer ^ FindPageableItemContainer();
abstract member FindPageableItemContainer : unit -> System.Web.UI.WebControls.IPageableItemContainer override this.FindPageableItemContainer : unit -> System.Web.UI.WebControls.IPageableItemContainer

Docs.summary: Retrieves the data-bound control that is associated with the control.
Docs.returns: The data-bound control that is associated with the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The data-bound control retrieved by this method references a data source object that contains the data that the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control pages. For the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control to be able to page this data, the data-bound control must implement the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.IPageableItemContainer> interface.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.FindPageableItemContainer%2A> method checks whether the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PagedControlID%2A> property is set to the ID of a data-bound control. If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PagedControlID%2A> property is not set, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.FindPageableItemContainer%2A> method goes up the stack of naming containers to look for a data-bound control. For example, if the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control is inside the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView.LayoutTemplate%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> template of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PagedControlID%2A> property does not have to be set. This is because the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.FindPageableItemContainer%2A> method can automatically find the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control by examining the control tree.

Docs.exception:
A control that implements the interface was not found on the page.
-or-
The control specified by the property does not implement the interface.
-or-
The control does not have a naming container.

MemberSignature.Value: protected internal override void OnInit (EventArgs e);
.method familyorassemblyhidebysig virtual instance void OnInit(class System.EventArgs e) cil managed
Protected Friend Overrides Sub OnInit (e As EventArgs)
protected public: override void OnInit(EventArgs ^ e);
abstract member OnInit : EventArgs -> unit override this.OnInit : EventArgs -> unit

Docs.summary: Raises the event.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When notified by this method, Web server controls must perform any initialization steps that are required in order to create and set up an instance. In this stage of the server control's life cycle, the control's view state has not yet been populated. Additionally, you cannot access other server controls when this method is called, regardless of whether it is a child or parent to this control. Other server controls are not guaranteed to be created and ready for access.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.OnInit%2A> method also enables derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

block.para: When you override in a derived class, make sure that you call the base class' method so that registered delegates receive the event.

.method familyorassemblyhidebysig virtual instance void OnLoad(class System.EventArgs e) cil managed
Protected Friend Overrides Sub OnLoad (e As EventArgs)
protected public: override void OnLoad(EventArgs ^ e);
abstract member OnLoad : EventArgs -> unit override this.OnLoad : EventArgs -> unit

Docs.summary: Raises the event.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.OnLoad%2A> method notifies the server control that it should perform actions that are common to each HTTP request for the page that it is associated with. At this stage in the page life cycle, server controls in the hierarchy are created and initialized. View state is restored, and form controls reflect values that were posted from the client. This implementation also invokes the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.FindPageableItemContainer%2A> method to find the container control that implements the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.IPageableItemContainer> interface, and it initializes the page properties.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.OnLoad%2A> method also enables derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

Docs.exception: A container control that implements the interface was not found.

block.para: When you override in a derived class, make sure that you call the base class' method so that registered delegates receive the event.

MemberSignature.Value: protected virtual void OnTotalRowCountAvailable (object sender, System.Web.UI.WebControls.PageEventArgs e);
.method familyhidebysig newslot virtual instance void OnTotalRowCountAvailable(object sender, class System.Web.UI.WebControls.PageEventArgs e) cil managed
Protected Overridable Sub OnTotalRowCountAvailable (sender As Object, e As PageEventArgs)
protected: virtual void OnTotalRowCountAvailable(System::Object ^ sender, System::Web::UI::WebControls::PageEventArgs ^ e);
abstract member OnTotalRowCountAvailable : obj * System.Web.UI.WebControls.PageEventArgs -> unit override this.OnTotalRowCountAvailable : obj * System.Web.UI.WebControls.PageEventArgs -> unit

Docs.summary: Handles the event.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.IPageableItemContainer.TotalRowCountAvailable?displayProperty=nameWithType> event when the total number of records in its underlying data source is available. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.OnTotalRowCountAvailable%2A> method is a handler for this event and is responsible for updating the page-related properties and recreating the pager field objects.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual string PagedControlID { get; set; }
.property instance string PagedControlID
Public Overridable Property PagedControlID As String
public: virtual property System::String ^ PagedControlID { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.PagedControlID : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the of the control that contains the data that will be paged by the control.
Docs.value: The of the control that contains the data that will be paged by the control. The default is an empty string, which indicates that this property is not set.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PagedControlID%2A> property to specify the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ID%2A> of the control that contains the data that will be paged by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control. The specified control must implement the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.IPageableItemContainer> interface and must use the same naming container as the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control. An example of a control that you can specify is the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control.
If this property is an empty string or `null`, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control checks whether its container control implements the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.IPageableItemContainer> interface. For example, in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PagedControlID%2A> property does not have to be set if you put the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control inside the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView.LayoutTemplate%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> template. This is because the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control can automatically find the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control by examining the control tree.
The value of this property is stored in view state.
## Examples The following example shows how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PagedControlID%2A> property to dynamically associate a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control with a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.%23ctor%2A> constructor.
[!code-csharp[System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.Ctor#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.Ctor/CS/DataPagerCtorCS.aspx#2)] [!code-vb[System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.Ctor#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.Ctor/VB/DataPagerCtorVB.aspx#2)]
The following example shows how to declaratively set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PagedControlID%2A> property in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control in order to page the data of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control.
[!code-aspx-csharp[System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PagedControlID#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PagedControlID/CS/DataPagerPagedControlIDCS.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PagedControlID#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PagedControlID/VB/DataPagerPagedControlIDVB.aspx#1)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the number of records that are displayed for each page of data.
Docs.value: The number of records that are displayed for each page of data. The default is 10.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PageSize%2A> property to specify the size of a page of data.
If you have multiple <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> controls in a page that are bound to the same <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control, be sure to set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PageSize%2A> property of these controls to the same value. If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> controls are set to use different page sizes, the last <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control to be initialized determines the actual page size of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control.
## Examples The following example shows how to declaratively set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PageSize%2A> property in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control and how to dynamically change its value.
[!code-aspx-csharp[System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PageSize#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PageSize/CS/DataPagerPageSizeCS.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PageSize#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.PageSize/VB/DataPagerPageSizeVB.aspx#1)]

Docs.exception: The property is set to a value less than 1.

MemberSignature.Value: public string QueryStringField { get; set; }
.property instance string QueryStringField
Public Property QueryStringField As String
public: property System::String ^ QueryStringField { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.QueryStringField : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the name of the query string field.
Docs.value: The name of the query string field. The default is an empty string, which indicates that the control will use a HTTP POST command to navigate through the pages.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.QueryStringField%2A> property to specify that the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control uses an HTTP GET command to navigate through the pages. In GET requests, a query string field that consists of a name/value pair is added to the URL of the page. The name is set by using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.QueryStringField%2A> property. The value is the corresponding page number. If <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.QueryStringField%2A> is an empty string or `null`, the control uses an HTTP POST command to navigate through the pages.
Setting this property is useful if you want to have all the pages of data indexed by a search engine. This occurs because the control produces a different URL for each page of data.
When you set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.QueryStringField%2A> property, the following conditions might apply:
- You have more than one <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control in a page and they reference the same data-bound control. In that case, make sure that the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.QueryStringField%2A> property of these <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> controls is set to the same value.
- You have more than one <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control in a page and they reference different data-bound controls. In that case, make sure that the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.QueryStringField%2A> property of these <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> controls is set to different values. If you set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> controls to the same value, the associated data-bound controls will be paginated at the same time, because they will use the same query-string field.
If you do not follow the previous guidelines, unexpected paging behavior can occur. However, no exception will be thrown by the control.
If <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.QueryStringField%2A> property is not an empty string or `null`, the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.NextPreviousPagerField.ButtonType%2A> property of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.NumericPagerField> or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.NextPreviousPagerField> objects is ignored. In that case, these objects use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.HyperLink> control to create their navigation buttons.
## Examples The following example shows how to declaratively set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.QueryStringField%2A> property in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control in order to navigate through the pages by using a query string. This example contains two <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> controls that are used to page through the data that is displayed by a single <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control.
[!code-aspx-csharp[System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.QueryStringField#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.QueryStringField/CS/DataPagerQueryStringFieldCS.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.QueryStringField#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.QueryStringField/VB/DataPagerQueryStringFieldVB.aspx#1)]

Docs.summary: Saves any changes to an control's view-state that have occurred since the time the page was posted back to the server.
Docs.returns: Returns the control's current view state. If there is no view state associated with the control, this method returns .

remarks.format:
## Remarks View state is the accumulation of the values of a server control's properties. These values are automatically put in the server control's <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ViewState%2A> property, which is an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.StateBag> class. This property's value is then persisted to a string object after the save-state stage of the server control life cycle. For more information, see [ASP.NET State Management Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/0218d965-5d30-445b-b6a6-8870e70e63ce(v=vs.100)).
When view state is saved, this string object is sent to the browser as a variable that is stored in a hidden element in the page. When you create custom server controls, you can improve efficiency by overriding this method and modifying the server control's `ViewState` property. For more information, see [ASP.NET State Management Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/0218d965-5d30-445b-b6a6-8870e70e63ce(v=vs.100)).
> [!NOTE] > This method is primarily used by control developers to extend the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.SetPageProperties%2A> method sets new values for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.StartRowIndex%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.MaximumRows%2A> properties. It also invokes the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.IPageableItemContainer.SetPageProperties%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method to update the page-related properties in the associated data-bound control.

## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.System%23Web%23UI%23WebControls%23ICompositeControlDesignerAccessor%23RecreateChildControls%2A> method enables a designer for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control to re-create the control's child controls at design time.

## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.TagKey%2A> property returns an HTML element that is used by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.RenderBeginTag%2A> method to write the appropriate markup for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control. This property overrides the base implementation to always return <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriterTag.Span?displayProperty=nameWithType>.
> [!NOTE] > This property is primarily used by control developers to extend the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control.

Docs.summary: Tracks view-state changes to the control so that they can be stored in the control's object. This object can be accessed through the property.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.TrackViewState%2A> method is called automatically at the end of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.Init> event in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control's life cycle. This method alerts ASP.NET to monitor changes to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> server control's view state.
